sense.name: relative strength of a chemical substance
sense.examples: The chemical is harmless in such small concentrations. The fumes can collect into a potentially explosive concentration below decks. That narcotic can be lethal in those concentrations.

sense.name: degree of spatial crowding together, density
sense.examples: That lake supports the largest concentration of Canada geese in the world. Most of the population lives in urban concentrations along the border. Bob's father survived a concentration camp during World War II. They hope the concentration of troops around the capital will reduce the current violence.

sense.name: the act of increasing or strengthening a solution
sense.examples: The concentration of grain alcohol occurs through a distillation process. Those labs are used for the concentration of uranium 235 isotopes for weapons-grade fissile material.

sense.name: a mental state of immersion, engrossment
sense.commentary: CONCENTRATION[+state][+mental][+immersion] Note: implies a single event of mental immersion
sense.examples: There was a look of complete concentration on the pianist's face as he began the piece. Immense concentration is required of simultaneous translators. The ringing telephone and barking dog broke my concentration.

sense.name: the act of directing attention, resources to something
sense.commentary: CONCENTRATION[+activity][+allocation][+large][+attention/+resources] Note: implies an ongoing allocation of attention or resources
sense.examples: The school's concentration on the learning disabled has resulted in a neglect of the gifted students. The concentration of effort in combatting this disease has been through educational channels. John's area of concentration as a math major is topology.
